articles.headline: In a New Era of Insider Trading, It’s Risk vs. Reward Squared
articles.snippet: As potential rewards have soared, the tactics and technologies available to inside traders today are more sophisticated and more difficult both to detect and to prove.
articles.abstract: As potential rewards have soared, the tactics and technologies available to inside traders today are more sophisticated and more difficult both to detect and to prove.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March 1991, Michael R. Milken, once the richest and most powerful financier of his generation, entered prison, signaling the end of an era of junk bond-financed hostile takeovers and high-visibility prosecutions that law enforcement officials hoped would deter insider trading for generations.

articles.headline: American Airlines All Clear for Bankruptcy Exit
articles.snippet: The pilots union approved a new contract, freeing American Airlines to come out of bankruptcy, and possibly pursue a merger with US Airways.
articles.abstract: The pilots union approved a new contract, freeing American Airlines to come out of bankruptcy, and possibly pursue a merger with US Airways.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the overwhelming vote on Friday by its last holdout labor group, the pilots, to approve a new contract, American Airlines and its creditors are now free to focus on the biggest issue ahead: should American pursue a merger with US Airways or remain independent for now?

articles.headline: As the Year Draws to a Close, Deciding How to Slice Your Charitable Pie
articles.snippet: This time of year, when charitable giving becomes rushed and routine, might be the best time to review how you divide your donations.
articles.abstract: This time of year, when charitable giving becomes rushed and routine, might be the best time to review how you divide your donations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each year at this time, out of some combination of generosity and procrastination, millions of Americans rush to make donations to the causes and institutions important to them.

articles.headline: Justices to Hear Two Challenges on Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: A California case could establish or reject a right to same-sex marriage, while a New York case contests a law denying federal benefits to couples married in those states that allow it.
articles.abstract: A California case could establish or reject a right to same-sex marriage, while a New York case contests a law denying federal benefits to couples married in those states that allow it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would enter the national debate over same-sex marriage, agreeing to hear a pair of cases challenging state and federal laws that define marriage to include only unions of a man and a woman.

articles.headline: Prank Call Seeking Royal Family Secrets Takes Horrifying Turn
articles.snippet: A nurse tricked by Australian D.J.’s who called posing as Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles to get information about Kate Middleton’s pregnancy was found dead on Friday.
articles.abstract: A nurse tricked by Australian D.J.’s who called posing as Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles to get information about Kate Middleton’s pregnancy was found dead on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As pranks go, this one appeared outrageous and obnoxious rather than malicious: after convincing a hospital nurse who answered the phone this week that they were Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles, two Australian radio hosts then tricked another nurse into disclosing medical information about the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge, who had been admitted with acute morning sickness.

articles.headline: Justices to Take Up Generic Drug Case
articles.snippet: The case involves a decade-long battle over whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.
articles.abstract: The case involves a decade-long battle over whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would decide whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor millions of dollars to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.

articles.headline: Canada Clears $15 Billion Chinese Takeover of an Energy Company
articles.snippet: The takeover would give China some footholds in the Gulf of of Mexico and the Canadian oil sands in the North Sea.
articles.abstract: The takeover would give China some footholds in the Gulf of of Mexico and the Canadian oil sands in the North Sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Canada on Friday allowed a Chinese state-run oil giant to move forward with $15 billion takeover of a domestic energy company, but the government indicated that such deals might not pass muster in the future.

articles.headline: Bid to Write New Rules for Funds Gains Ally
articles.snippet: A member of the S.E.C. who had been opposed to a proposal to overhaul the money market fund industry has had a change of heart.
articles.abstract: A member of the S.E.C. who had been opposed to a proposal to overhaul the money market fund industry has had a change of heart.
articles.lead_paragraph: A type of mutual fund could lose its trademark stable value of $1 a share after a crucial government official voiced his support for controversial efforts to overhaul the $2.6 trillion money market fund industry.

articles.headline: In WikiLeaks Case, Defense Puts the Jailers on Trial
articles.snippet: While Pfc. Bradley Manning faces a life sentence if convicted, his lawyer is demanding answers about his treatment at the Marine base where he was kept.
articles.abstract: While Pfc. Bradley Manning faces a life sentence if convicted, his lawyer is demanding answers about his treatment at the Marine base where he was kept.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — In a half-empty courtroom here, with a crew of fervent supporters in attendance, Pfc. Bradley Manning and his lawyer have spent the last two weeks turning the tables on the government.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Certified Safe, a Factory in Karachi Still Quickly Burned
articles.snippet: Retail giants have helped create and champion numerous factory inspection systems, but industry-backed auditing was no protection for at least 262 Pakistanis who died in a September blaze.
articles.abstract: Retail giants have helped create and champion numerous factory inspection systems, but industry-backed auditing was no protection for at least 262 Pakistanis who died in a September blaze.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The century-old Central Jail here, a gritty repository of criminals, jihadists and sectarian killers, has a reputation for overcrowding and prisoner riots. But for Arshad and Shahid Bhaila, the industrialist brothers whose factory burned to the ground in September, killing at least 262 workers, there are some comforts.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: Backing Off Added Powers, Egypt’s Leader Presses Vote
articles.snippet: President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt rescinded most of a temporary order elevating his authority but did not postpone a referendum on a draft constitution, a critical opposition demand.
articles.abstract: President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt rescinded most of a temporary order elevating his authority but did not postpone a referendum on a draft constitution, a critical opposition demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Struggling to quell violent protests that have threatened to derail a referendum on an Islamist-backed draft constitution, President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt moved Saturday to appease his opponents with a package of concessions hours after state news media reported that he was moving toward imposing a form of martial law to secure the streets and allow the vote.

articles.headline: A Vault for Taking Charge of Your Online Life
articles.snippet: Reputation.com is building a business around helping people store personal data about themselves as a way to manage their online reputations.
articles.abstract: Reputation.com is building a business around helping people store personal data about themselves as a way to manage their online reputations.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.

articles.headline: Chevron Aims at an Activist Shareholder
articles.snippet: Chevron subpoenaed a hedge fund’s shareholder proposals as it tries to find ammunition in its fight against an $18 billion judgment in Ecuador.
articles.abstract: Chevron subpoenaed a hedge fund’s shareholder proposals as it tries to find ammunition in its fight against an $18 billion judgment in Ecuador.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUBLIC corporations routinely tell shareholders that their views matter. The Chevron Corporation, for example, said in its 2012 proxy statement: “Your board welcomes dialogue on the topics presented in the stockholder proposals on the following pages.” So it might seem odd that last month Chevron subpoenaed one of its investors, Trillium Asset Management, which has sponsored numerous shareholder proposals at Chevron over the years. The oil company demanded documents related to those proposals. The subpoena also asked for records of discussions Trillium had about these proposals with the media.

articles.headline: Big Money Bets on a Housing Rebound
articles.snippet: Investment companies have spent billions of dollars to buy thousands of individual homes in hopes of reaping big profits when the industry rebounds.
articles.abstract: Investment companies have spent billions of dollars to buy thousands of individual homes in hopes of reaping big profits when the industry rebounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVID N. MILLER, a master of bailouts, steps to the dais and coolly explains how the financial world went crazy.

articles.headline: Tax Arithmetic Shows Top Rate Is Just a Starter
articles.snippet: Despite hints that President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner might compromise on the tax rate paid by top earners, a host of other tax questions could still derail a fiscal deal.
articles.abstract: Despite hints that President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner might compromise on the tax rate paid by top earners, a host of other tax questions could still derail a fiscal deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite hints in recent days that President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner might compromise on the tax rate to be paid by top earners, a host of other knotty tax questions could still derail a deal to avert a fiscal crisis in January.

articles.headline: A Family, for a Few Days a Year
articles.snippet: Hundreds of children have been stranded in orphanages in Guatemala for years as authorities there weigh whether to approve their adoptions by families in the United States.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of children have been stranded in orphanages in Guatemala for years as authorities there weigh whether to approve their adoptions by families in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — The little boy flies like an airplane through the hotel, his arms outstretched. Then he leaps like a superhero, beaming as the red lights on his new sneakers flash and flicker, while the American couple he is with dissolve in laughter.

articles.headline: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
articles.snippet: The United States faces a challenge, as some of the best fighters in an uprising that it wants to support belong to a group that it considers a terrorist organization.
articles.abstract: The United States faces a challenge, as some of the best fighters in an uprising that it wants to support belong to a group that it considers a terrorist organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The lone Syrian rebel group with an explicit stamp of approval from Al Qaeda has become one of the uprising’s most effective fighting forces, posing a stark challenge to the United States and other countries that want to support the rebels but not Islamic extremists.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Clinton’s Countless Choices Hinge on One: 2016
articles.snippet: With her tenure as Secretary of State coming to an end, Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be a figure of nearly limitless possibility, but her next few years could ultimately be defined by her plans for the 2016 election.
articles.abstract: With her tenure as Secretary of State coming to an end, Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be a figure of nearly limitless possibility, but her next few years could ultimately be defined by her plans for the 2016 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’re one of the most famous women on earth, and you’re jobless for the first time in decades. You’d like to make money, but you don’t want to rule out running for president. So what do you do all day?

articles.headline: Mortgage Crisis Presents a New Reckoning to Banks
articles.snippet: A torrent of lawsuits could add significantly to billions of dollars of settlements in mortgage securities cases.
articles.abstract: A torrent of lawsuits could add significantly to billions of dollars of settlements in mortgage securities cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest banks are facing a fresh torrent of lawsuits asserting that they sold shoddy mortgage securities that imploded during the financial crisis, potentially adding significantly to the tens of billions of dollars the banks have already paid to settle other cases.

articles.headline: Opponents of Egypt’s Leader Call for Boycott of Charter Vote
articles.snippet: The Egyptian opposition signaled that it had given up hope of defeating the draft constitution at the polls and would opt instead to try to undermine the referendum’s legitimacy.
articles.abstract: The Egyptian opposition signaled that it had given up hope of defeating the draft constitution at the polls and would opt instead to try to undermine the referendum’s legitimacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The political crisis over Egypt’s draft constitution hardened on both sides on Sunday, as President Mohamed Morsi prepared to deploy the army to safeguard balloting in a planned referendum on the new charter and his opponents called for more protests and a boycott to undermine the vote.

articles.headline: Browser Wars Flare Again, on Little Screens
articles.snippet: Shaping the browsers of the future has become a spirited struggle among the big tech companies that see the mobile world as a make-or-break business.
articles.abstract: Shaping the browsers of the future has become a spirited struggle among the big tech companies that see the mobile world as a make-or-break business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Google took a video camera to Times Square in 2009 and asked passers-by what a browser is, most of the answers were hilariously incorrect, from “a search engine” to “broadband” to “Yahoo.”

articles.headline: Fed Is Likely to Sustain Its Stimulus Program
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve must still determine what to buy and how much to spend, and officials continue to debate the best way to describe when the agency is likely to stop buying.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve must still determine what to buy and how much to spend, and officials continue to debate the best way to describe when the agency is likely to stop buying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is widely expected to announce on Wednesday that it will continue buying Treasury securities to stimulate growth in the new year.

articles.headline: For The Journal, Leadership at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: As News Corporation splits into two companies, The Wall Street Journal’s future lies in the hands of two executives with mixed track records.
articles.abstract: As News Corporation splits into two companies, The Wall Street Journal’s future lies in the hands of two executives with mixed track records.
articles.lead_paragraph: Betting against Rupert Murdoch hasn’t gone very well for many people, including me. When he bought The Wall Street Journal in 2007 and brought in a trusted associate, Robert Thomson from The Times of London, I said that he might ruin one of the country’s most important newspapers.

articles.headline: In Pursuit of McAfee, Media Are Part of Story
articles.snippet: A canny manipulator of the press, the software pioneer John McAfee teased many a reporter to his Central American lairs only to spin tales that were surreal and often unverifiable.
articles.abstract: A canny manipulator of the press, the software pioneer John McAfee teased many a reporter to his Central American lairs only to spin tales that were surreal and often unverifiable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, the editor in chief of Vice magazine, Rocco Castoro, joined by a photographer, Robert King, managed to secure a plum exclusive: an invitation to travel along with the fugitive tech millionaire John McAfee.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Weighs Making Bid for The Financial Times
articles.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg, who has an affinity for The Financial Times, is said to be weighing the wisdom of buying the newspaper if it is put up for sale by Pearson.
articles.abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, who has an affinity for The Financial Times, is said to be weighing the wisdom of buying the newspaper if it is put up for sale by Pearson.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, The Financial Times would have been the crown jewel of any media company, instantly conferring prestige and influence on its owner. Now, given the likely bidders, one of the world’s most respected and distinctive financial newspapers could end up as a trophy to help sell more computer terminals.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Same-Sex Issue Pushes Justices Into Overdrive
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court’s hearing of two cases on gay marriage could result in a split decision that would provide benefits to couples in some states, but permit other states to forbid same-sex marriages.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court’s hearing of two cases on gay marriage could result in a split decision that would provide benefits to couples in some states, but permit other states to forbid same-sex marriages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Life moves fast these days, and so does the law.

articles.headline: Chinese Firm Wins Bid for Auto Battery Maker
articles.snippet: The sale of A123, a battery maker, to Wanxiang Group, a Chinese auto parts maker, is the latest acquisition of an American energy and manufacturing company by a Chinese firm.
articles.abstract: The sale of A123, a battery maker, to Wanxiang Group, a Chinese auto parts maker, is the latest acquisition of an American energy and manufacturing company by a Chinese firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Wanxiang Group, a large Chinese auto parts maker, won a high-stakes auction on Sunday for assets of A123 Systems, the bankrupt American battery maker that was a centerpiece of the Obama administration’s loan program for electric vehicles.

articles.headline: 113th Congress: This Time, It’s Out With the New
articles.snippet: Instead of fresh faces, many of the recently elected members of the House of Representatives are career bureaucrats and policy wonks with deep histories in politics and government.
articles.abstract: Instead of fresh faces, many of the recently elected members of the House of Representatives are career bureaucrats and policy wonks with deep histories in politics and government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a fund-raiser for a local college scholarship program, Rick Nolan understands how much it costs to send children in northern Minnesota to technical school. Having run a sawmill, he can speak like a logger.

articles.headline: Amgen to Acquire the Gene-Hunting Firm deCODE
articles.snippet: In a bid to bolster its drug discovery efforts, the biotechnology giant Amgen said on Monday that it would pay $415 million to acquire deCODE Genetics, a gene-hunting business known for its headline-grabbing discoveries linking genetic variations ...
articles.abstract: In a bid to bolster its drug discovery efforts, the biotechnology giant Amgen said on Monday that it would pay $415 million to acquire deCODE Genetics, a gene-hunting business known for its headline-grabbing discoveries linking genetic variations to disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a bid to bolster its drug discovery efforts, the biotechnology giant Amgen said on Monday that it would pay $415 million to acquire deCODE Genetics, a gene-hunting business known for its headline-grabbing discoveries linking genetic variations to disease.
